properties.name: Quick Facts
description: Providence Canyon is not natural contrary to popular belief
It was a result of poor farming practices popular in the 1930s
Erosion has exposed millions of years of the geological record
The canyon is a network of gorges, chasms, cliffs, and plateaus
Unlike the landscape history of something like the Grand Canyon the gullies of this canyon was sculpted by farm water runoff instead of natural agents like rivers, streams, and wind
The different colors represent different elements present in the kaolin
Lavender results from manganese. Tan, yellow, pink, and red are from different levels of iron oxidization with the ground water.

properties.name: Main Canyon Wall
description: The canyon reaches depths of 150 feet
Clays and sand construct much of the canyon
The white clay is called Kaolin aka Kaolinite
The clays are stained by different chemical weathering processes
Clay colors range from white, yellow, pink, purple, and red
43 colors have been identified

properties.name: Water Table
description: Erosion has caused exposure of the underlying water table
The deepest parts of the canyon have a thin layer of water on the ground
Water is present year round even during the dry seasons
The iconic magnolia trees grow as a result of the unusual amounts of moisture

properties.name: Magnolia Plant
description: Thrives in moist humid environments
Blooms in the fall season
Dependent on rich soil accumulated at the bottom of water holes
Providence Canyon is the only place in Georgia where they bloom
Magnolia cannot grow anywhere else due to unconsolidated sediments and erosion

properties.name: Kaolinite
description: Kaolinite is a soft, earthy, usually white mineral resembling clay
Formed by the chemical weathering of aluminum silicate minerals like feldspa
Kaolinite is extensively mined in Ga ~$1 bilion a year
Mining is restricted to near-surface processes
Kaolin is mined using diesel or electric drills and draglines
Kaolin is used in toothpaste, Pepto Bismol, cat litter, and porcelain

properties.name: Erosion
description: Main agent is surface water runoff
Erosion in the canyon is categorized into vertical and lateral erosion
Vertical erosion is minimal because the clay-rich soils absorb a lot of surface runoff
The dense vegetation also protects against vertical erosion
Lateral erosion is a continuous process because the soft upper soils are subject to sudden changes
This is why the canyon is growing larger every year

properties.name: Chemical Weathering
description: Desert varnish is the thin, dark surface veneer of iron and manganese oxides that coats exposed rocks, especially in hot deserts
It results from the surface precipitation of minerals released from the rock by chemical weathering
Many of the canyon walls display striations that are most likely due to the trickling of water

properties.name: Canyon Loop Trail
description: Approx. 2.5 mi long trail
The trail circles nine of the canyons
Climbing, even walking, near the the sides of the canyon is hazardous
Hazards include soil fall of unconsolidated sediments
Silt/clay avalanches (very rapid)
Soils on the sides are similar to quicksand

properties.name: Providence Formation
description: The Providence Formation (Cretaceous Period in age) is composed of sand and clay, including white kaolin clay lenses, and cross-bedding in some of the sand layers
The Clayton Formation (Tertiary Period in age) is red-orange, iron-rich, sandy clay, and caps the top of the canyon.
Between the two formations is an unconformity, or gap in geologic time formed by erosion as the sea level changed.
